item.title: GPs told to guarantee same-day appointments for urgent cases
item.content:encoded: New contract will require patients in England to be given immediate appointment if needed.

item.title: Reform by-election campaign boss suspended over tweets
item.content:encoded: Reform UK's Gorton and Denton by-election interim campaign boss Adam Mitula made the posts on X.

item.title: BBL death investigation dropped after suspect dies
item.content:encoded: Mum-of-five Alice Webb died in 2024 after becoming unwell following cosmetic treatment.

item.title: PSG's Hakimi to face trial after rape allegation
item.content:encoded: Paris St-Germain defender Achraf Hakimi says he is set to face trial after an allegation of rape was made against him.

item.title: Nancy Guthrie's family offers $1m reward to bring home missing mother
item.content:encoded: Fighting back tears, the missing woman's NBC host daughter says they accept she may be dead.

item.title: Government publishes thousands of Sturgeon inquiry files
item.content:encoded: Ministers have released a tranche of documents after the information commissioner launched legal action.

item.title: Why Champions League return is crucial to Man Utd
item.content:encoded: Up to fourth in the Premier League after Monday's win at Everton, Champions League qualification would be a big boost to Manchester United's finances after two years outside Europe's elite club competition.

item.title: BBC edited a second racial slur out of Bafta ceremony
item.content:encoded: The BBC's chief content officer Kate Phillips says a slur that aired was the result of a genuine error.

item.title: Man 'caused wife's death by controlling her', jury told
item.content:encoded: Christopher Trybus denies the manslaughter of his wife Tarryn Baird who took her own life in 2017.

item.title: Trump's new tariff comes into effect at lower than expected rate
item.content:encoded: The global levy comes in at 10%, lower than the rate the president had threatened at the weekend.

item.title: Lammy to lift cap on court sitting days to cut cases backlog
item.content:encoded: The justice secretary said every crown court in England and Wales will be funded to hear as many cases as possible next year.

item.title: 'It bothers me that Vinicius' celebration is being used against him'
item.content:encoded: Real Madrid goalkeeper Thibaut Courtois says Vinicius Jr's celebration against Benfica in last week's Champions League tie does not "justify a suspected act of racism".

item.title: New stadium curse - are Everton showing how clubs struggle after move?
item.content:encoded: As Everton's home form continues to struggle, BBC Sport takes a closer look at the curse of the new stadium in the Premier League era.

item.title: What does the new law on school uniforms mean in Northern Ireland?
item.content:encoded: BBC News NI having been looking at they key aspects of the new guidelines.

item.title: UK finally welcomes milder weather after rainy start to 2026
item.content:encoded: How high will temperatures reach and how long will stay mild? Darren Bett has the details.

item.title: Mexico hunts 23 inmates sprung from jail during wave of violence
item.content:encoded: The prisoners escaped from a jail in Puerto Vallarta after armed men rammed one of the gates.

item.title: Reddit fined £14m for 'concerning' child age check failings
item.content:encoded: The UK's data watchdog said the failings meant children could be exposed to harmful material online.

item.title: Reddit fined £14m for 'concerning' child age check failings
item.content:encoded: The UK's data watchdog said the failings meant children could be exposed to harmful material online.

item.title: Phillipson defends student loan change and says average repayments will rise by £8 a month
item.content:encoded: Some graduates in England say "punishing" student loan repayments have led them to cut their hours at work.

item.title: Reform vows to overhaul pension schemes for new local government workers
item.content:encoded: Reform plans to end more generous defined benefit pension schemes for new local government workers if it wins office.

item.title: A Woman's Hour and SEND in the Spotlight special
item.content:encoded: We hear from a range of voices on the impact of the government's SEND reforms in England.

item.title: Ireland defeat reminiscent of end of my England era - Jones
item.content:encoded: Former England coach Eddie Jones says the team's defeat by Ireland left him feeling sick as it brought back memories of the end of his own time in charge.

item.title: Chocolate kept in anti-theft boxes as shops warn it's being stolen to order
item.content:encoded: Retailers and police forces tell the BBC that thieves are targeting chocolate and selling it on.

item.title: Chocolate kept in anti-theft boxes as shops warn it's being stolen to order
item.content:encoded: Retailers and police forces tell the BBC that thieves are targeting chocolate and selling it on.

item.title: Trump to address a changed America at vital moment for his presidency
item.content:encoded: Few of Donald Trump’s speeches to Congress have had as much riding on them as the one on Tuesday night.

item.title: In maps: Tracking the war with Russia
item.content:encoded: How Russia's gradual gains in the face of fierce Ukrainian opposition have affected the front line in recent months.

item.title: 'Anyone who runs is shot': Watch Russian soldiers describe killings of troops who refuse orders
item.content:encoded: The men, who are on the run, told of the horrors they witnessed on the Russian side of the front lines in Ukraine.

item.title: Why it's going wrong for Aston Martin ahead of the new Formula 1 season
item.content:encoded: The combination of Adrian Newey, Honda and Fernando Alonso was highly promising but Aston Martin are in trouble. Andrew Benson explains why.

item.title: Why has it gone so wrong for Aston Martin?
item.content:encoded: The combination of Adrian Newey, Honda and Fernando Alonso was highly promising but Aston Martin are in trouble. Andrew Benson explains why.

item.title: Clothing bank faces closure as donations fall
item.content:encoded: Clothing Coventry has been operating since 2020, and needs £50,000 a year to keep the doors open.

item.title: I don't want him going abroad to die, says mum of son's assisted dying wish
item.content:encoded: Shelley Herniman was against Noah's wish for an assisted death but his suffering changed her mind.

item.title: What happened to Arlene? The 30-year mystery of a murder without a body
item.content:encoded: Arlene Fraser's husband Nat is serving life for murder - but her family is still seeking answers about what happened to her body.

item.title: Bowen: Why Ukraine remains defiant and does not feel close to defeat
item.content:encoded: This month marks four gruelling years since the full‑scale invasion began and a genuine ceasefire still feels far from assured

item.title: Russian soldiers tell BBC they saw fellow troops executed on commanders' orders
item.content:encoded: Four men expose the horror and brutality of conditions in the Ukraine war, with two saying they saw soldiers being shot for refusing orders.

item.title: Number of workers on zero-hours contracts hits record high ahead of crackdown
item.content:encoded: There has been a 181,000 increase in the number of zero-hours contracts since Labour was elected.

item.title: Trump Organization unveils plan for 'Australia's tallest building'
item.content:encoded: The tower will be built on Queensland's Gold Coast and be 335 metres high, taller than the Shard in London.

item.title: FedEx sues for Trump tariff refund
item.content:encoded: The US Supreme Court ruling that the US president overstepped when imposing levies paved the way for firms to seek a refund.

item.title: First British baby born using transplanted womb from dead donor
item.content:encoded: Grace Bell, who was born without a viable womb, says her little boy is "simply a miracle".

item.title: Orbital space race heats up in Arctic north
item.content:encoded: Europe lags far behind the US and China in orbital space launches, but new facilities are opening up.

item.title: 'A conman stole my money and bought his wife a 10-carat diamond ring'
item.content:encoded: US victims have lost hundreds of thousands of dollars to a gang of UK and Irish nationals, known as The Travelling Conmen.

item.title: Trump threatens countries that 'play games' with existing trade deals
item.content:encoded: The threat comes after the Supreme Court ruled on Friday that Trump had exceeded his authority in enacting a sweeping global programme of tariffs.

item.title: Peter Mandelson Arrested
item.content:encoded: Lord Mandelson arrested on suspicion of misconduct in public office

item.title: No 10 says ‘nothing off the table’ over new US tariffs as UK could be among worst hit
item.content:encoded: Downing Street says discussions are ongoing following US President Donald Trump's announcement of a 15% global tariffs.

item.title: Company director jailed over £7m airline parts fraud
item.content:encoded: The judge said the actions were a "more or less complete undermining" of rules designed to ensure passenger flights are safe.

item.title: When is the Spring Statement and what might be in it?
item.content:encoded: Chancellor Rachel Reeves will give an update on her plans for the UK economy when she gives a statement alongside an economic forecast on 3 March.

item.title: Unlicensed betting firms face sponsorship ban
item.content:encoded: Gambling firms not licensed in the UK could be banned from sponsoring British sports teams - including Premier League clubs - as part of a government crackdown.

item.title: Netflix boss defends bid for Warner Bros as Paramount deadline looms
item.content:encoded: Ted Sarandos says his company's offer is better for industry growth as it is "buying assets we don't currently have".

item.title: Porn company fined £1.35m by Ofcom over age check failings
item.content:encoded: Ofcom's £1.35m fine on 8579 LLC is the largest it has levied under the Online Safety Act so far.

item.title: What now for Asia after Trump's tariffs struck down?
item.content:encoded: After the Supreme Court ruling, Trump said he would impose new levies of 15% on goods entering the US.

item.title: 'It's cheaper to ship gluten-free food from the UK'
item.content:encoded: A Guernsey mum is calling for cheaper and a greater choice of gluten-free foods for her family.

item.title: How budget fast fashion is taking small-town India by storm
item.content:encoded: More Indians in small towns are now shopping for affordable brands instead of unlabelled goods in the bazaars.

item.title: Are you cut out for living and working in Antarctica?
item.content:encoded: Jobs are available on the icy continent for chefs, plumbers, carpenters and even hairdressers.

item.title: The uncertainties facing businesses and consumers after Trump's tariff changes
item.content:encoded: Businesses say questions remain after US President Donald Trump announced he will impose global tariffs of 15%.

item.title: Funding approved to reduce cold deaths
item.content:encoded: Citizens Advice's Warm and Well scheme in North Yorkshire will receive the money over three years.

item.title: Trump says he will increase his new global tariffs to 15%
item.content:encoded: After most of his tariffs were outlawed on Friday, Trump announced new global tariffs of 10% - which he says he has now increased to 15%.

item.title: Key social issues identified in charity report
item.content:encoded: Each year, Citizens Advice selects social policy areas for analysis based on its clients' issues.

item.title: MPs to discuss inquiry into trade envoy role after Andrew arrest
item.content:encoded: A cross-party committee will also look into the appointment and accountability of UK trade envoys.

item.title: 'It is a catastrophe' - the man battling to stem rising youth unemployment
item.content:encoded: Alan Milburn returns to his hometown of Newcastle as he undertakes a review into the growing numbers of young people out of work.

item.title: Is £70 becoming harder to justify? The rise of cheaper blockbuster games
item.content:encoded: As top games such as GTA 6 are speculated to cost $100 (£74), some developers are deliberately pricing lower.

item.title: UK agrees drone defence plan with four EU allies
item.content:encoded: The scheme will seek to take inspiration from Ukraine's drone manufacturing programme.

item.title: Trump tariffs ripped up global trade order. What now?
item.content:encoded: If you think the Supreme Court ruling heralds a return to pre-Trump business as usual - think again.

item.title: KFC, Nando's, and others ditch chicken welfare pledge
item.content:encoded: Wingstop, Burger King, and others have walked away from an industry commitment to avoid using fast-growing chickens

item.title: Lobbying firm co-founded by Mandelson goes into administration
item.content:encoded: Global Counsel's clients cut ties with the firm over Lord Mandelson's links with sex offender Jeffrey Epstein.

item.title: When the retail staff can't help you
item.content:encoded: This customer might be feeling trolled, in this scene from Small Prophets.

item.title: Higher tax helped UK government reach record January surplus
item.content:encoded: The government took in more from tax receipts than expected, official data suggests.

item.title: How do you modernise mango farming?
item.content:encoded: India's mango farmers are being urged to innovate as climate change makes cultivation "unpredictable".

item.title: The two farms in Senegal that supply many of the UK's vegetables
item.content:encoded: During winter in Britain fresh produce is sent by cargo ship from the West African nation every week.

item.content:encoded: Unemployment in the UK rose to its highest rate in nearly five years at the end of 2025

item.content:encoded: Reddit says its human contributors are valued amid an internet awash with AI-generated content.

item.content:encoded: The US president wants American energy firms to start extracting the crude but they are reluctant.

item.title: Why you should consider switching bank accounts

item.title: The US economy is growing - so where are all the jobs?
item.content:encoded: As hiring rates and job openings drop, some worry a tough job market could be here to stay.

item.title: Get a grip: Robotics firms struggle to develop hands
item.content:encoded: Developing a durable and affordable hand is one of the biggest challenges in robotics.

item.content:encoded: The industrialist and Manchester United co-owner has apologised over comments he made about immigration.

item.title: The Dutch love four-day working weeks, but are they sustainable?
item.content:encoded: The Netherlands has the lowest working hours in Europe, but some say it is harming its economy.

item.title: How £50m 'fish disco' could save farmland
item.content:encoded: Innovative tech scares fish away from nuclear cooling pipes.

item.title: Why food fraud persists, even with improving tech
item.content:encoded: Even with sophisticated technology it is still difficult to detect fake foods.

item.title: Plane makers chase Asia's super-rich with luxe new private jets
item.content:encoded: Parts of the aviation industry are shifting towards wealthy customers and selling a more luxurious type of international travel.

item.title: The real impact of roadworks on the country - and why they're set to get worse
item.content:encoded: There is a fine balance between the benefits of improved infrastructure, versus the cost of disruption. Does the country have it right?

item.title: Why the railways often seem to be in such chaos over Christmas
item.content:encoded: Parts of Britain’s rail network will close for engineering work over the festive period - but is that the right time to do it?
